About ShoveBoss


Defining Nash Equilibrium

A Nash Equilibrium situation in poker is defined when players ranges are in equilibrium with each other, or in other words, when opponents are playing an "optimal" game against one another whereby they both cannot gain anything by deviating from equilibrium strategy. This leads to an eventual stalemate (long term break-even proposition) and it makes no sense for either opponet to deviate from Nash if the other player is strictly following Nash - this means they will be deviating from "optimal" strategy and the other player may benefit. If one player deviates from Nash then the other player can do better by re-adjusting their ranges accordingly. Note that the word optimal remains inverted since following Nash will be far from optimal in a lot of situations.

What ShoveBoss does?

ShoveBoss calculates all his Shoving Ranges according to Nash Equilibrium
The conclusion is pushing even more than ShoveBoss suggests is advantageous, because most of the players do not know the correct range to call and in practice will call a lot tighter than they should. Specially shoving from Late positions you can shove way more than ShoveBoss Nash Equilibrium calculations.


However, you must understand that if you push a hand profitably according to Nash Equilibrium it does not mean that this is the best action in a given situation. Sometimes raise-fold or raise-call gives you more Expected Value (+EV) than shoving even if you are Short Stack.
Also, you should adjust your range playing the bubble stage in a tournament and shove tighter in those stages than ShoveBoss suggests.
